items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Terrorists No Match for Single City Cop
items.abstract: The first novel by the “Law & Order” creator Dick Wolf, “The Intercept” provides a sense of insiderdom in an otherwise standard detective novel about a terrorist plot.

items.title: Disruptions: Design Rivals Technology in Importance
items.abstract: As consumers focus less on the technology inside the technology, designers have stepped in to add more value to devices.

items.title: Providence Is Top City in Contest of Ideas
items.abstract: In a contest overseen by Bloomberg Philanthropies, Mayor Angel Taveras won his city $5 million to help parents improve the vocabulary of their children.

items.title: City Health Officials Warn Some Men on Lethal Strain of Meningitis
items.abstract: Over the last two years, it has appeared only in men, believed to be contracted through anonymous sexual encounters with other men. But health officials fear an outbreak.

items.title: Robert Tuggle, Longtime Archivist of the Metropolitan Opera, Dies at 83
items.abstract: Mr. Tuggle helped create a digital database that includes details from every performance since the Met opened with Gounod’s “Faust” on Oct. 22, 1883.

items.title: Open Subway Cars May Come to New York City as Early as 2020
items.abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could award a contract as early as next year to build 10 of them, officials said, bringing to life an idea that has been debated for years.

items.title: Britain Aims to Strengthen North’s Cities
items.abstract: Under a “Northern Powerhouse” plan, the government has pledged to build more roads and railways, invest in technology and research hubs, and even appeal to China’s development bank for funds.

items.title: City Steps Up Gas Line Inspections After Fatal Blast in East Village
items.abstract: A city department conducted 343 inspections of gas plumbing last year, five times as many as in 2014, and has hired additional inspectors in the past year.

items.title: The Making of Prada’s Understated, Architectural Set
items.abstract: Rem Koolhaas’s OMA team breaks down the latest set in its 15-year long collaboration with the fashion house.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: The Army, in Need of Recruits, Turns Focus to Liberal-Leaning Cities
items.abstract: Too few recruits are signing up from cities like Chicago and Seattle, so the Army is trying to frame enlistment as a patriotic detour.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: To Save the Sound of a Stradivarius, a Whole City Must Keep Quiet
items.abstract: A team in Cremona, Italy, wants to preserve every note from the world’s finest instruments before they become too fragile to play. But perfect recordings need silence. Lots of it.

items.title: Those Wild ‘Masked Singer’ Costumes? She Designed Them
items.abstract: Marina Toybina got her big break working on a Britney Spears music video. Now she’s behind the elaborate animal costumes on Fox’s hit show.

items.title: As If by Design, Their Connection Was Inevitable
items.abstract: William Ackman had been given two nudges by two friends to reach out to Neri Oxman. He found they were both right.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: Cooper Hewitt Design Museum Gets a New Director
items.abstract: Maria Nicanor, an architecture curator and historian, takes on the Smithsonian position held by Caroline Baumann, who in 2020 was abruptly forced to resign.

items.title: Celebrating Black History Month? These 5 Cities Are Going All Out
items.abstract: Honoring all things African-American, with performances, river cruises, exhibitions and more, in Richmond, Va., Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Cleveland and San Antonio.

items.title: The N.F.L. Wants to Be a Player in a City of Players
items.abstract: The league’s new West Coast headquarters, in the shadow of SoFi Stadium, gives it a large footprint in the land of big media deals.

items.title: He’s Springing Forward to Move City Clocks to Daylight Time
items.abstract: Marvin Schneider, the New York City clock master, has a busy weekend ahead.
